After numerous engagements in important opera houses in Budapest and Germany, he became first conductor at the Berlin State Opera (1924), retaining this post for five years. In 1929 he was appointed first conductor of the National Theatre in Prague. When he resigned from this post in 1936 Szell succeeded John Barbirolli as conductor of the Glasgow Symphony Orchestra. He also appeared as guest conductor throughout Europe and Australia.

In 1940 Szell went to the United States, making his American debut at the Hollywood Bowl. In New York City he conducted the National Broadcasting Company Symphony Orchestra (1941) and the orchestra of the New Friends of Music (1941-42). In 1942 he was appointed guest conductor of the Metropolitan Opera House, New York. He was also a teacher at the Institute of Musical Art. In 1946 Szell went to Cleveland, where he stayed until his death. He is remembered for his long and successful tenure as music director and conductor of the Cleveland Orchestra, and for his numerous recordings.
text_he:
מנצח ומלחין. נולד בבודפשט, הונגריה. בגיל 11 ניגן עם התזמורת הסימפונית של וינה ובגיל 17 ניצח על התזמורת הפילהרמונית של ברלין. היה המנצח של בית האופרה הגרמני בפראג (1921-1919), מנצח ראשי של בית האופרה הממלכתי של ברלין (1930-1924) ומ1937- ניצח גם על התזמורת הסקוטית בגלאזגו ועל התזמורת המלכותית בהאג, הולנד. ב-1940 הגיע לארה"ב והיה מנצח ראשי של המטרופוליטן אופרה, ניו-יורק (1945-1942). ב-1946 מונה למנצח של תזמורת קליבלנד, ותפקיד זה מילא עד מותו. לימד בכיתות הלימוד לאופרה בבית הספר החדש למחקר חברתי בניו-יורק ובבית הספר למוסיקה על שם מאנס.
הלחין, בין השאר, נושא וואריאציות לתזמורת (1916), ופתיחה לירית (1922). נפטר בקליבלנד, אוהיו (ארה"ב).

text_en:
Szenkar, Eugen )Jeno) (1891-1977), conductor, born in Budapest, Hungary (then part of Austria-Hungary). He was the son of an organist and composer. After studying at the Budapest Conservatory he was engaged by the Budapest Opera.  In 1912 he became a conductor at the National Theatre in Prague, Czech Republic. 1915 he was conductor of the Volksoper in the same city. In 1923, after conducting opera and symphony at Altenburg and Frankfurt he was appointed general music director of the Volksoper in Berlin, Germany, in succession to Otto Klemperer. He held this post for only one year, after which he was called to the Koln  Opera to become first conductor. There, he was the first conductor to perform "The Wonderful Mandarin" by Bela Bartok and "The Love of three Oranges by Prokofjev". He also conducted there Hary Janos, by Zoltan Kodaly.

When the Nazis came to power in Germany, in 1933, Szenkar was compelled to leave. He became conductor of symphony concerts in Budapest, and was invited to conduct a few guest performances with the Palestine Symphony Orchestra. He also conducted in Moscow, Russia, and Rio de Janeiro, Brasil. After WW II he returned to Germany.

Szenkar composed several large works for orchestral and chamber groups.
text_he:
1891 – 1977
נולד בבודפשט, הונגריה, אז חלק מאוסטריה-הונגריה. אביו היה נגן אורגן ומלחין. 

למד בקונסרבטוריון של בודפשט ולאחר מכן עבד באופרה של בודפשט. 

בשנת 1912 נתמנה למנצח בתיאטרון הלאומי בפראג, הרפובליקה הצ'כית. ב- 1915 ניצח על האופרה Volksoper בפראג. ניצח על אופרה ועל סימפוניה באלטנבורג ובפרנקפורט וב- 1923 נתמנה למנהל ה Volksoper בברלין, גרמניה, תפקיד שקודם מילא אוטו קלמפרר. הוא החזיק במשרה הנכבדה שנה אחת, ואז נענה להזמנה מהאופרה של קלן להיות מנצח ראשי. הוא היה הראשון לבצע את "מנדרין הפלא" של בלה ברטוק ואת "אהבה לשלושה תפוזים" של פרוקופייב. הוא הופיע כמנצח גם עם "הארי יאנוש" של זולטאן קודאי.

text_en: Composer. Born in Prague, Czechoslovakia, he studied at the conservatories of Prague and Leipzig (among others, with Reger). He earned world fame with his comic opera SCHWANDA THE BAGPIPER, which was performed in Prague in 1927. It combined tuneful melody with Czech and Slovak folk music. The polka and fugue from the opera are often performed in orchestral concerts. He also wrote HEBREW SONG (1936). In 1939 he went to the United States, settled in New York City and started using American folk-music material in his works as in UNDER THE SPREADING CHESTNUT TREE (1939), THE LEGEND OF SLEEPY HOLLOW for orchestra (1940) and THE LINCOLN SYMPHONY (1941). Weinberger also composed the operas OUTCASTS OF POKER FLAT (1932; based on the story by Bret Harte) and WALLENSTEIN (1937), and the ballet SARATOGA (1941). Depressed by his inability to be part of the American music scene he committed suicide in St. Petersburg, Florida (USA). His manuscripts are preserved at the National and University Library in Jerusalem.
text_he: מלחין. נולד בפראג, צ'כוסלובקיה. למד בקונסרבטוריונים בפראג ובלייפציג (בין היתר, אצל רגר). האופרה הקומית שלו שוואנדה נגן חמת החלילים, שהועלתה בפראג ב-1927, זיכתה אותו בפרסום עולמי. האופרה שילבה נעימות מתוך הפולקלור הצ'כי והסלובקי. הפולקה והפוגה מתוך אופרה זו מבוצעות לעתים קרובות בקונצרטים. כמו כן, כתב שיר עברי (1936). ב-1939 הגיע לארה"ב, התיישב בניו-יורק והתחיל להשתמש בחומרים מן המוסיקה העממית האמריקנית (כך, למשל, בתחת צמרתו המתפשטת של עץ הערמונים, 1939, באגדת Sleepy Hollow לתזמורת, 1940, ובסימפוניית לינקולן, 1941). ויינברגר חיבר גם את האופרות Outcasts of Poker Flat (1932; מבוססת על הסיפור מאת ברט הארט) ווואלנשטיין (1937), ואת הבלט סאראטוגה (1941). דיכאון אחז בו עקב אי יכולתו להשתלב בחיי המוסיקה באמריקה והוא התאבד בסנט פיטרסבורג, פלורידה (ארצות-הברית). כתבי היד שלו שמורים בספרייה הלאומית והאוניברסיטאית בירושלים.

text_en:
Weisgall, Hugo (1912- 1997), composer, born in Ivancice, Moravia, Czech Republic (then paert of Austria-Hungary). Weisgall was eight years old when he immigrated to the United States. From 1927-1932 he studied piano, harmony and composition at the Peabody Conservatory in Baltimore. He was the conductor of Har Sinai Temple Choir (1931-1942) and the Youth Alliance Orchestra (1935-1842) in Baltimore. In 1952 he was Chairman of the Cantor’s Institute of the Jewish Theological Seminary in New York.
His works deal with social and moral issues and his style is usually expressionistic atonal, sometimes twelve-tone, idiom. In 1944 his first significant work – SOLDIER SONG –was published. His operas include THE TENOR (per.1952), THE STRANGER (per. 1952), SIX CHARACTERS IN SEARCH OF AN AUTHOR (per. 1959), PURGATORY (per. 1961) and JENNY, OR THE HUNDRED NIGHTS (per. 1976). Died in New York.
text_he:
וייסגל, הוגו (1912-1997), מלחין

נולד באיוואנציצה (Ivancice), מורביה רפובליקה צ'כית (אז חלק מאוסטריה-הונגריה). 

וייסגל היה בן שמונה כשהגיע לארה"ב. בשנים 1932-1927 למד פסנתר, הרמוניה וקומפוזיציה בקונסרבטוריון פיבודי בבלטימור. היה מנצח של מקהלת בית הכנסת הר סיני (1942-1931) ושל התזמורת Youth Alliance בבלטימור. ב-1952 כיהן כיושב הראש של מכון החזנות של הסמינר היהודי התיאולוגי בניו-יורק.

יצירותיו עוסקות בנושאים חברתיים ומוסריים וסגנונו, בדרך כלל, אקספרסיוניסטי-אטונלי, לפעמים בטכניקה הדודקפונית. ב-1944 פורסמה יצירתו הגדולה הראשונה, שיר חיילים. היצירה האופראית שלו כוללת את הטנור (ביצוע 1952), הזר (ביצוע 1952), שש נפשות מחפשות מחבר (ביצוע 1959), גיהנום (ביצוע 1961), וג'ני, או מאה הלילות (ביצוע 1976). נפטר בניו-יורק, ארה"ב.

text_en:
Weltsch, Robert (1891-1982), journalist and prominent Zionist in Weimar Germany, born in Prague, Czech Republic (then part of the Austria-Hungary). Prague city had a strong Jewish community which was culturally German. His father, attorney Theodore Weltsch, was active in local Jewish public affairs and at the turn of the century served as director general of the "Centralverein zur Pflege Jüdischer Angelegenheiten" ("Central Society for Handling Jewish Affairs"), founded in Prague in 1885.

In 1910, Weltsch graduated from the German gymnasium of the Alt-Stadt in Prague, and went on to study law at the Karl-Ferdinand German University of Prague. He was a member of  the Zionist student association Bar Kochba, and between 1910 and 1914 he published articles in German-language Zionist newspapers including the Prague-based weekly "Selbstwehr" as well as in "Die Welt". During World War I he served as an officer of the Austrian army on the Russian front.  During this period he continued to write articles for the German-language Zionist press.

While wishing to see a large Jewish community living in Palestine, he strongly favoured a future bi-national state in which both Jews and Arabs would live side by side.  Weltsch’s reservations about the establishment of a Jewish nation-state in Palestine constituted just one component of his critical attitude toward the very principle of self-determination of national groups within multiethnic territories. He regarded the actual implementation of this principle in East Central Europe after World War I as a fateful mistake, whose origin he traced to the “unnatural,” external intervention of the United States. 

Shortly after WW I, Zionist leaders in Germany invited Weltsch to Berlin to serve as editor in chief of "Jüdische Rundschau", the official journal of the Zionist Federation of Germany and one of the most widely read interwar publications in the Jewish world. It appeared twice per week andt its peak the magazine had a regular readership of over 35,000. Because of his consistent adherence to the binational cause and his critical approach toward the policies of the mainstream Zionist movement, Weltsch often faced attempts to depose him as the editor of "Juedische Rundschau". Nevertheless, he held this post until 1938, when the Nazis forced the newspaper to cease publication. 

From 1925 to 1933 Weltsch was active in the Zionist "Brit Shalom" movement which advocated the binational solution for Palestine in which he believed. His newspaper's reaction to Hitler's rise to power was an article of 1933 in which it was written that “we understand the psychological and intellectual basis” of the Nazi policies and respect their goal of national renewal.  “This, after all what the Zionists want for the Jews.   We believe that a nationally conscious Jewry could find its way to a modus vivendi with an inwardly strengthened Geman nationalism freed from the dross of crude anti-Semitism.” 
Weltsch's most famous article was published immediately after the Nazis had organized a boycott of all Jewish-owned shops in 1934. In the article Weltsch wrote "Wear it with pride, the yellow badge”. It was a call for strength, solidarity and unity amongst the Jews amongst German Jews who until then had been very fragmented and made every effort to assimilate into German life. (His phrase was not a reference to the wearing of the yellow armband which Jews were obliged to wear from 1941). Wetsch had passionately agreed with the comment of the editor of the Vossische Zeitung who a short time earlier had written “...from a higher standpoint anti-Semitic oppression has perhaps turned out to be a boon, in that a far greater number of German Jews than ever before are becoming more mindful of their traditions and their great past.”

In 1935 the "Juedische Rundschau" was temporarily closed after Weltsch asserted that “The Jew is a human being also” after a Goebbels' speech labelling Jews subhuman “flees”.
After fleeing to Palestine in 1938, he continued agitating for accommodation with the Arab population of Mandate Palestine. Weltsch had wished to recommence publication of the "Juedische Rundschau" in Palestine, but he encountered vigorous opposition from the Hebrew newspaper establishment on account of his controversial views.
Weltsch worked for "Haaretz" and in 1945 he moved to London, England, to become the newspaper's correspondent  there. In this capacity he covered the Nuremberg Trials. He was a major force in establishing the Leo Baeck Institute in London, which is dedicated to preserving German-Jewish culture and is named after the rabbi and leader of the German-Jewish community during the Nazi years. Weltsch edited the Institute's Yearbook from 1956 to 1978. From that time until his return to Jerusalem in 1978, he made a substantial contribution to the newspaper as a political journalist, a political analyst and book reviewer.
text_he:
1891 – 1982
עתונאי ופעיל ציוני 
נולד בפראג, הרפובליקה הצ'כית (אז חלק מאוסטריה-הונגריה)
בפראג היתה אז קהילה יהודית חזקה בעלת תרבות גרמנית.
אביו, תאודור ולטש, היה עורך דין ופעיל ציבור בנושאי הקהילה. בשנת 1900 בקירוב כיהן האב כמנהל "האגודה המרכזית לעניינים יהודיים", שנוסדה בפראג ב- 1885.
בשנת 1910 סיים ולטש את לימודיו בגימנסיה הגרמנית באלטשטדט בפראג, והתחיל ללמוד משפטים באוניברסיטה הגרמנית קארל-פרדיננד בפראג. הוא היה חבר באגודת הסטודנטים הציונים "בר כוכבא". בשנים 1910 – 1914 פרסם מאמרים בעתונים ציוניים בגרמנית כולל השבועון Selbstwehr בפראג וה"די וולט". בזמן מלחמת העולם הראשונה שירת כקצין בצבא האוסטרי בחזית הרוסית. באותה תקופה לא פסק מכתיבת מאמרים לעתונות הציונית בשפה הגרמנית.
תקוותו היתה לראות קהילה יהודית גדולה בישראל, והעדפתו הפוליטית נטתה להקמתה בעתיד של מדינה דו לאומית שבה יחיו יחד יהודים וערבים. הוא הסתייג מהקמת מדינת לאום יהודית בישראל, ובאופן כללי מהגדרה עצמית של קבוצות לאומיות באזורים מרובי קבוצות אתניות. הוא ראה ביישום עקרון זה במזרח אירופה אחרי מלחמת העולם הראשונה טעות גורלית, שמקורה לדעתו בהתערבותה החיצונית והלא טבעית של ארצות הברית.
בתום מלחמת העולם הראשונה, הזמינו מנהיגים ציונים בגרמניה את ולטש לברלין לכהן כעורך ראשי ב Jüdische Rundschau, העתון הרשמי של הפדרציה הציונית בגרמניה ואחד הנפוצים ביותר בעולם היהודי בין שתי מלחמות העולם. העתון יצא פעמיים בשבוע והיו לו בתקופת השיא יותר מ 35,000 קוראים. בשל תמיכתו ברעיון הדו לאומי וגישתו הביקורתית כלפי מדיניות הזרם המרכזי בציונות, ניסו לא אחת להיפטר ממנו כעורך, ובכל זאת כיהן בתפקידו עד 1938, כשהנאצים אסרו על פרסום העתון. 
מ- 1925 עד 1933 היה ולטש פעיל בתנועה הציונית "ברית שלום", שקידמה את הפתרון הדו לאומי בישראל. תגובת עתונו לעליית היטלר לשלטון היתה מאמר מ- 1933 שבו נכתב "אנו מבינים את הבסיס הפסיכולוגי והאינטלקטואלי של מדיניות הנאצים ומכבדים את שאיפתם לתחייה לאומית. זה בעצם מה שרוצים הציונים עבור היהודים. אנו מאמינים כי יהדות בעלת מודעות לאומית תוכל למצוא דרך לקיים מודוס ויונדי עם לאומיות גרמנית פנימית משוחררת מרפש האנטישמיות הבסיסית".
מאמרו המפורסם ביותר של ולטש יצא לאור מיד אחרי שהנאצים ארגנו חרם על כל העסקים בבעלות יהודית ב- 1934. הוא כתב "ענדו בגאווה את הטלאי הצהוב". הוא קרא לעוצמה, סולידריות ואחדות בקרב היהודים הגרמנים שעד אז היו מפולגים וביקשו להיטמע בחיים הגרמנים. הוא לא התכוון לסרט הזרוע הצהוב שנכפה על היהודים מ- 1941. ולטש תמך בלהט בדבריו של עורך ה Vossische Zeitung שזמן קצר קודם לכן כתב "מנקודת מבט כוללת, ייתכן שטמונה בדיכוי האנטישמי ברכה, שכן יותר ויותר יהודים נהיים מודעים למסורתם ולעברם".
ב- 1935 נסגר ה Juedische Rundschau זמנית, אחרי שולטש טען "היהודי הוא בן אנוש גם אחרי נאומו של גבלס שכינה את היהודים פרעושים ותת אדם" הוא נמלט לישראל ב- 1938 והמשיך להפיץ את רעיון החיים המשותפים עם הערבים. ולטש ביקש לחדש את תפוצת עתונו גם בישראל, אך נתקבל בהתנגדות חזקה מצד ארגון העתונות העברית בשל דעותיו השנויות במחלוקת.
הוא עבד בעתון "הארץ" ובשנת 1945 עבר ללונדון ונהיה כתב "הארץ" שם. בתפקידו זה כיסה את משפטי נירנברג. הוא השתתף ביסוד מכון לאו בק בלונדון, שמוקדש לשימור התרבות היהודית-גרמנית וקרוי על שמו של רב ומנהיג יהודי בתקופה הנאצית. ולטש ערך את שנתון המכון מ- 1956 עד 1978. עד שובו לירושלים ב- 1978 כתב בעתון פרשנות פוליטית וביקורת ספרים.

text_en: Conductor. Born in Czechoslovakia, he first studied medicine. From 1903-1918 he was conductor of the Czech Philharmonic Orchestra. He died in Czechoslovakia.
text_he:
מנצח. נולד בצ'כוסלובקיה. למד רפואה לפני קריירת הניצוח. 
בשנים 1908-1913 כיהן כמנצחה של התזמורת הפילהרמונית הצ'כית. נפטר בצ'כוסלובקיה.

text_en:
1836 - 1917
Scholar

Born in Ungarisch-Brod, Moravia, he studied under Samson Raphael Hirsch at Nikolsburg and then at the Rabbinical Seminary and University of Breslau (Wroclaw). He then served as rabbi in various communities including Gniezno where he officiated from 1864 to 1869. From 1898 he was rabbi of the Mora-Leipziger Foundation in Breslau. His great contribution to Jewish scholarship was his scientific edition of the Tosefta ( the body of early rabbinic teaching, closely related to the Mishnah).
text_he:
1836 - 1917
רב והוגה דעות
נולד באונגריש ברוד, מורביה

למד אצל שמשון רפאל הירש בניקולסבורג, ואחר במכון הרבני בברסלאו (ורוצלאב).

כיהן כרב בקהילות רבות, ביניהן בגנייזנו, שם היה רב 1864 – 1869. משנת 1898 כיהן כרב בקרן מורה-לייפציגר בברסלאו. תרומתו הגדולה להגות היהודית היתה מהדורה מדעית לתוספתא.

text_en:
Rabbi

He was born in Dolny Kubin, Czech Republic (then part of the Austrian Empire) and studied in Budapest, Hungary, at the Rabbinical Seminary and at the university. While a student, he was attracted by Reform, and from 1888 was liberal rabbi in Karlsbad (now Karlovy Vary, Czech Republic). He made many contributions to the community and was a supporter of Zionism. His main publications were in the fields of Bible, Talmud and Midrash, religious philosophy, and Jewish history.

Altmann, Maria (1918-2011), refugee from Nazi occupied Austria, born in Vienna, Austria, as Maria Viktoria Bloch-Bauer to a wealthy family whose businesses and home were confiscated by the Nazis. 

Shortly after her marriage, her husband Fritz was arrested and then held in the Dachau concentration camp in order to force his brother Bernard, who had fled to France, to transfer the Bernard Altmann textile factory to the Germans. After the release of Fritz, the couple fled to England where they lived for a short time before immigrating to the USA settling in Fall River, MA, and then in Los Angeles. Most of their family and friends were murdered by the Nazis.

Maria was the niece of Czech businessman and art collector Ferdinand Bloch whose collection included several paintings by Gustav Klimt. When Bloch died in 1946 he left his collection to a nephew and two nieces, one of whom was Maria Altmann. During the Nazi period Bloch’s property had been looted and at the end of war some of the paintings were found to be held by the Austrian government. In the 1980s  Altmann attempted to negotiate the return of the Klimt landscape paintings to her family while she was prepared to allow Austria to keep the portraits. The Austrians claimed that Bloch’s wife, who had died in 1925, had willed the paintings to the national gallery in Vienna. But it seems that they had no real evidence to support their claim. The Austrians made no attempt to negotiate the matter seriously so in 1999 Altmann sued the Austrian government. She dropped the case when the Austrian courts demanded a $350,000 filing fee. She then filed a lawsuit in California which ended up in the USA Supreme Court and which ruled in 2004 that the Austrian government was not immune from such a lawsuit. This time the Austrians agreed to arbitrate the matter seriously. In 2006 the arbitration court ruled that the Austrians should return the paintings and this was finally done. They were put on display at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. When the paintings were ultimately sold they were auctioned for some $416 million. It was the largest single return of Nazi looted art in Austria. 
 
Maria Altmann’s story has been the subject of three documentary films.

Aszod, Judah Ben Israel (1794-1866), rabbi, born in Aszod (Pest region), Hungary (then part of the Austrian Empire). He studied at the yeshivah of Rabbi Mordechai Banet in Nikolsburg, Moravia (now in the Czech Republic). He received his rabbinical diploma at the age of 22. At first Aszod served as rabbi in Reth, later in Szenice. From 1826 to 1830 he served as dayyan in Dunaszerdahely (now Dunajska Streda, Slovak Republic), and later in other communities, and from 1853 he was Chief Rabbi of Dunaszerdahely, and headed a yeshivah there, which attracted many pupils. He was a member of the Orthodox rabbinical delegation to the Emperor Franz Joseph in Vienna in 1864, which appealed to him to cancel the proposed plan for a government-sponsored rabbinical seminary. Aszod was much respected by his co-religionists, as well as by the Christian population.

Aszod's collection of responsa, "Teshuvot Maharia" (Moreno ha'Rav Judah Aszod), also called Jehudah Ya'aleh (1873), arranged according to the four divisions of the "Shulhan Arukh", is regarded as one of the best works of its kind. He also published several collections of insights into the Torah and Talmudic themes named "Hiddushei Maharia".

Baschwitz, Zvi Hirsch ben Meir (1680-1722), born in Bornat Brzecz in Lithuania (now Brest, in Belarus). Baschwitz was attracted to the printing trade, the “sacred profession”, as it was called when it referred to the printing of prayer books. In Berlin, Germany, he worked at the Hebrew press of court preacher Professor David Ernst Jablonsky. In 1708 he moved to Frankfurt an der Oder and in 1719 he arrived in the small town of Dyhernfurth, in Prussian Silesia (now Poland). In 1719 Zvi Hirsch Baschwitz became  a member of  Shabbetai Bass’s team. 
  
The town had been founded in 1663, when the Austrian emperor Leopold I, wishing to reward the Silesian chancellor, Baron von Dyhern, gave his estate the rights and status of a city with the name "Dyhernfurth". In 1667 the baron obtained permission to set up a Hebrew printing house there. The only other Hebrew printing press in the region was in Prague (now in the Czech Republic). In 1668 the press was set up by Shabbethai ben Joseph Bass under the patronage of Baron von Glaubitz, the new lord of the estate and of the city. The workers of the printer established a Jewish community there — the first in Silesia since the expulsion of the Jews from that province in 1584.

Boehm, Vilmos (Wilhelm) (1880-1948), labor leader, born in Budapest, Hungary (then part of Austria-Hungary). An electrician by trade, Boehm became active in the labor movement and rose rapidly to the ranks of its leaders. During the short-lived Karolyi regime in Hungary (1918) he was appointed state secretary in the ministry of war, and in the radical Berinkey cabinet which followed he became minister of war. During the Bolshevik Revolution in Hungary he was first Commissar of War, and then commander-in-chief of the Communist army (1919). 

After the fall of the Communist dictatorship, he fled to Vienna, Austria. There, from 1920 to 1936 he was an energetic publicist and pamphleteer, writing some effective anti-Fascist broadsides. After the assassination of Dollfuss (1938), Boehm fled to Prague, Czech Republic (then Czechoslovakia) and then to Paris, France, where he lived in semi-retirement with many Social Democratic comrades. He then moved to Sweden and served as the first Ambassador of Hungary to Sweden after WW2. He is suspected to have been a Soviet agent and put Raoul Wallenberg's name on the list of people arrsted by the Soviets after the capture of Budapest in 1945.

He published his memoirs under the title "Ket forradalom tuezeben" (In the Fire of two Revolutions, 1923). He also wrote "Kenyeret es munkat" (Bread and Labor); "Magyar szocialpolitika" (Hungarian Social Politics); "A munkasok es a forradalom" (The Workers and the Revolution); "A haborus korszak buenei" (Wartime Crimes). 

Vilmos Boehm had no formal contact with the Jewish community.

Brunschwig, Robert Emmanuel (1888-1944), rabbi, community leader and resistance member during World War 2, born in Altkirch, Alsace, France (Then part of Germany). Brunschwig studied at the Hildesheimer Rabbinal Seminary in Berlin, Germany, and, at the same time, he attended courses at the University of Berlin. His first appointment was that of military chaplain of the Saar region in western Germany, when it was occupied by France after World War I. He resigned from this position in 1920 when he was appointed rabbi of the "Etz Haim" orthodox congregation in Strasbourg.  He held the position for twenty years during which time he organized a intensive and well regarded Talmud Torah directed by Salomon Speier, a pupil of Rabbi Salomon Breuer and in 1926, established a branch of the Yechouroun youth movement which had originally been founded by Samson Raphael Hirsch in Germany. 

Yechouroun's members included many future leaders of the French Orthodox Jewish community including Samy Klein, Aron Wolf, Théo Klein (1913-2007), Antoinette Feuerwerker, Rose Warfman, Salomon Gluck, Josy Eisenberg, Benjamin Gross, Jacquot Grunewald, Henri Ackermann, Liliane Ackermann, André Neher, Gilles Bernheim andRené Gutman.   

From 1932 Brunschwig began to send students to the recently founded Yeshiva of Montreux in Switzerland. He was a member of the Agudat Yisrael movement and participated in its third assembly held in Marienbad, now in the Czech Republic, in 1937.
  
After the armistice in 1940, Rabbi Brunschwig again took up the duties of army chaplain in Vichy France. He went to Lyons where he became rabbi of a small congregation and  took care of the needs of the city's Orthodox community and in particular of those who had fled from Paris and the north of France and were now living in many parts of the town. He became an active member of the Resistance movement and was frequently in danger of being arrested. In an effort to protect him, he was given a forged certificate of citizenship of the state of San Salvador. Nevertheless he, together with his wife, were arrested in May 1944. They were killed in Auschwitz within two weeks.

Industrialist

Member of an important Cairo family of merchants and community leaders, he studied engineering in Paris and on returning to Cairo in 1882 he became an official in the ministry of public works. After studying sugar manufacture in Moravia, in the Czech lands, he directed a sugar plant in Egypt and established other industrial plants. Cattaui entered politics in 1915 and was a member of the Egyptian delegation to London which established Egyptian independence. In 1922 he was on the committee which drafted the Egyptian constitution. From 1924 he was minister of finance, then in 1925 minister of communications and served as a senator from 1927 to 1936.

Cerbu , Eva (1924-2008), painter, born as Eva Siegler in Bucharest, Romania. She studied at the Academy of Fine Arts (Scoala de Arte Frumoase) in Bucharest where she was a student of the painters M.H. Maxy and Al. Ciucurencu. She traveled extensively to Bulgaria, Soviet Union, Germany, France, Italy, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, Israel, and Greece. 

In addition to fiftyeen personal exhibition in Bucharest and another cities in Romania, from 1956 to 1996, she also participated in numerous collective exhibitions in Romania and abroad, including Prague, Czech Republic (1947, 1953, 1961, 1966); Budapest, Hungary (1948, 1953, 1960); Sophia, Bulgaria (1955, 1962, 1966); Warsaw, Poland (1958); Moscow, Russia (1959, 1975); Belgrad, Serbia (1960); Riga, Latvia (1960); Vienna, Austria (1961, 1969); Bratislava, Slovakia (1960); Venice, Italy (1961); Damascus, Syria (1961); Leipzig, Germany (1960); Cairo, Egypt (1962); Ljubljana, Slovenia (1961); Athens, Greece (1962); Habana, Cuba (1962); Bruxelles, Belgium (1964); Tel Aviv, Israel (1968, 1994); Beirut, Lebanon (1969); Lisbon, Portugal (1975); Oslo, Norway (1975); Perth, Australia (1976); Caracas, Venezuela (1978, 1980); Lyngby, Denmark (1985); Buenos Aires, Argentina (1991); Beijing, China (1994). 

Her works are displayed in museums in Romania, USA, Switzerlan, Italy, Netherlands, Germany, Israel, Mexico, France.

Dombovary (Schulhof), Geza (1848-1918), legal researcher, born in Dombovar, Hungary (then part of the Austrian Empire), the son of Adolf Schulhof, a well known physician. He attended high school at Pecs, Hungary, after which he studied at the universities of Vienna, Austria; Prague, Czech Republic and Budapest. He was a prominent activist in the movement for Jewish emancipation during the 1870's. At the same time he contributed to the crystallization of civil and penal law in Hungary. 

Dombovary's monumental two-volume work, entitled "Az ervenyben levo Magyar buntetoetorvenyek  gyuejtemenye" ("Collection of valid Hungarian Penal Code"),  1884, was hailed as the most comprehensive exposition of the penal code in Hungarian. Four years later he investigated the procedures of the Hungarian Supreme Court and compared them with procedures in foreign courts. His findings were published in a three-volume work known as "A Magyar buentetoetoervenykoenyv magyarazata: ("Explanation of the Hungarian Book of Penal Laws"). He was also author of "Munkasmozgalom Magyarorszagon" ("Labor Movement in Hungary"), a primary source book dealing with the labor movement in Hungary. Emperor Franz Joseph elevated him (1885) to the knighthood in reward for services in researching and clarifying the laws governing the nobility.

Geza Dombovary (Schulhof) was the father of Geza Robert Dombovary, Jr.

Einhorn, Ignatz (1825-1877) (also known as Eduard Horn), rabbi, economist and politician, born in Vagujhely, Hungary (then part of the Austrian Empire, now Nove Mesto, Slovakia). Einhorn studied at yeshivot at Nitra, Pressburg (now Bratislava, Slovakia) and Prague (now in the Czech Republic) and then at the University of Budapest. An ardent Hungarian nationalist, he was determined to create a Judaism suitable for Hungarians whom “were the Jewish faith”.  In 1847 he organized the Society for Reform of Judaism in Pest, and as rabbi of the Society's first temple introduced several changes (such as observing the Shabbath on Sunday). In 1848 he published Judenfrage in Ungarn ("The Jewish question in Hungary") and founded the weekly Der Ungarische Israeli ("The Hungarian Jew"), which propagated Reform Judaism. He edited the first Jewish-Hungarian Yearbook and wrote for the Allgemeine Juedische Zeitung, and the Orient.

As a decided liberal, he took part in the Hungarian Revolution in 1848, first as a revolutionary speaker in Budapest, and then as an army chaplain at Komorn. He helped to found the Society for the Propagation of Hungarian Language and Culture. He wrote for the Pester Zeitung newspaper.    Thereafter he was he was forced to flee Hungary. He went to Leipzig, Germany, where he published several books and articles about the situation in Hungary, changed his name to Eduard Horn, and studied philosophy and political economy. In 1851 he wrote ”Die Revolution und die Juden in Hungarn”

In 1851, Einhorn published the first volume of a book on Ludwig Kossuth, journalist, politician and Governor-President of Hungary in 1849 who was acclaimed as a freedom fighter and bellwether of democracy in Europe. To avoid extradition, Einhorn was obliged to flee once more. He went to Brussels, Belgium, where he studied French and English. In 1856, he moved to Paris, France, where several of his works on economics were published in the Journal des Debats, and in 1867 he received the Grand Prix of the French Academy for his L'economie politique avant les Physiocrates. At the same time in pamphlets and articles he continued his war of words against the policies of the Austrian government.  

After the Austro-Hungarian treaty of 1867, Einhorn returned to Hungary. In 1869 he was elected to Parliament, and in 1875 became assistant secretary to the Hungarian Ministry of commerce, the first Hungarian Jew to hold high office. At this time he assisted in preparing the laws granting the Jews equal rights in Hungary. In the arguments between Orthodox and Reform Judaism on this occasion he supported the former. By government decree, a memorial tablet has been fixed to the house where he was born and a street in Budapest was named after him.

Evenari, Michael (1904-1989), botanist, born in Metz, France, of German descent.He grew up as Walter Schwarz in the vicinity of Marburg, Germany, and studied botany at the universities of Frankfurt and Prague, Czech Republic. He carried our research in France, Czechoslovakia and Germany. He became a lecturer at the Technical High School in Darmstadt, Germany, but on account of his Jewishness ancestry he was dismissed from his position in April 1933 without notice. He emigrated to Palestine.

During World War II he served in the Jewish Brigade. When he was demobilised he lectured at universities in the USA and South America.  

Evenari was appointed professor of botany at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem and then, from 1952 to 1957, he was Dean of the Faculty of Science at the Hebrew University.   Between 1953-59 he was vice president of the Hebrew University. In his research Evenari made a significant contribution to the development of farming in the Negev desert in Israel and, at the same time, he greatly increased the knowledge of desert ecology. To this end he studied the farming methods of the Nabateans, Romans and Byantines.    He also studied the influence of red and infra-red light on the germination of seeds an the determination of the food value of algae for livestock and large scale cultivation. He established experimental farms in Shivta and Avdat, Israel, in order to check his findings. In 1977 he was awarded a Honorary doctorate from the Darmstadt Technical High School. In 1988 he was awarded the Otto Ludwig Lange prized for his  contribution to productivity and ecology of plants, especially in arid zones. Evenari wrote many articles and a number of books on his speciality and served on several UNESCO bodies.

Fischer, Gyula (Julius) (1861-1944), scholar and rabbi, born in Sarkeresztur, Hungary (then part of the Austrian Empire). Fischer graduated from the Hungarian Rabbinical Seminary and recipient of a Ph.D. from the University of Budapest, Fischer was appointed Neolog rabbi of Gyor (Raab) in 1887, then, in 1898, of Prague (now in the Czech Republic), and of Budapest in 1905. In 1905 he was appointed to the position of  lecturer in rabbinic literature at the Rabbinical Seminary - a position which he held until 1941. From 1913 he also taught Midrash. For some time he directed the Seminary. Fischer served as Chief Rabbi of Budapest from 1921 to 1943.
   
A man of wide Jewish learning, he translated into Hungarian Philo's "Life of Moses" (1925) and several other works. He wrote a biography of Judah ibn Tibbon (1885) and contributed articles in both German and Hungarian to a variety of Jewish and general publications including "Hatzofeh", "Magyar Zsido Szemle", "Egyenloseg", "Mult es Jovo", "Pester Lloyd", and "Ujsag".

Fischer was one of the first Hungarian Neolog rabbis to support the Zionist enterprise in of Erez Israel. In 1944 he was arrested by the Nazis and perished in one of the death camps, probably Matthausen.

Felberman, Henry (1850-1927), author, born in Mandok, Hungary (then part of the Austrian Empire). He studied at Pressburg (Pozsony, now Bratislava, in Slovakia),and later attended the universities of Prague, Czech Republic, and Berlin, Germany, specializing in philology. He was awarded a doctorate in 1873. Felberman then moved to Paris, France, where he established a school of languages named The Tower of Babel. In Paris he also contributed to various French publications including "Evenement" and "Republique Francaise" and collaborated with George Sand and Judith Gauthier. In 1877 Felberman settled in London, England, where he was co-founder of the "United Service Gazette" (1879), and in 1880 became editor of the "Examiner and Life".  Later he moved to Frankfurt, Germany, and there published "The English Mail". Among his books were "Die Ethik Spinozas"; "Geschichte der Mauren"; "Ueber Maimonides"; "Der Turm von Babel and Das Land der Sagas"; "Frueher und spaater"; "Castle Nemes"; "Mein Traum, Wie ich meinen Beruf verfehlte"; "Ein Soziales Erdbeben"; "Nur ein Weib" and others.

Frankl, Adolf (1859-1936),rabbi, banker and communal leader, born in Debrecen, Hungary (then part of Austria-Hungary). He was recognized as a brilliant Talmudic scholar at the Yeshiva of Pozsony (now Bratislava, in Slovakia), and also that of  Nagyvarad (now Oradea, in Romanian,). He was ordained as a rabbi in Pressburg although he had no intention of pursuing a rabbinical career.  

His chose banking as a career but almost immediately upon leaving school Frankl became involved in communal service.   He was involved in public affairs both inside and beyond the Jewish community. For eighteen years he served as member of the Budapest municipal council. In 1888 he was made Nasi of the Hungarian Kolel in Jerusalem. Frankl was a lifelong student of Jewish history and traditions. Proficient in several languages, he became an inspiring leader of the Orthodox Jews in Hungary, and corresponded with Orthodox leaders in several countries

In 1905 he was unanimously elected national head of the Orthodox Union. After the death of Rabbi Koppel Reich, Frankl was chosen to be chief rabbi of the Orthodox community. As such he became a member of the upper chamber of the Hungarian Parliament. He played a significant role in helping to resolve disputes between the Orthodox and Neologs, and was respected by all sections of the Jewish  community. Frankly wrote articles for many publications mainly on Jewish themes such as Halachah and responsa.

Friedlander, Moritz (1842-1919), communal worker and historian, born in Burszentgyorgy, Hungary (then part of the Austrian Empire). He studied at the University of Prague (now in the Czech Republic), and although he prepared for a rabbinical career, he did not pursue the idea on account of his liberal views. After a short period as a teacher he became in 1875 secretary of the Viennese Israelitische Alliance which did benevolent work amongst beleaguered Jewish communities. The work required visits to Galicia where, in cooperation with the Alliance Israelite Universelle, his organization aided exiled Russian Jews to migrate to the United States.

Friedlander's experience of the conditions under which the Jews were living in Galicia prompted him to agitate for and to establish, the first Jewish public school in the province. A record of his journeys was published in Fuenf Wochen in Brody. Baron Maurice de Hirsch, whose endowment funds were partially devoted to the establishment of educational institutions for Jewish children in Galicia, found in Friedlander an articulate spokesman for his ideas and appointed him secretary of the Baron de Hirsch Fund. Under his supervision more than fifty such schools were founded in Galicia by the Hirsch Fund in the years 1885-1900. Due to his efforts a further fund, in the name of Baroness Clara de Hirsch, of some five million francs was set up for the establishment of technical schools for Jewish girls. 

Friedlander was an expert on Hellenistic philosophy and the origins of Christianity. He published a number of books on this subject including "Ueber den Einfluss der Griechischen Philosophie auf das Judentum und Christentum" (1872); "Patristische und Talmudische Studien" (1878); "Apion: ein Culturbild aus dem ersten christlichen Jahrhundert" (1882); "Philo's Philantropie des juedischen Gesetzes" - translation and commentary (1889); "Zur Entstehunggeschichte des Christentums" (1894); "Das Judenthum in der vorchristlichen griechischen Welt" (1897); "Der vorchristliche Juedische Gnosticismus" (1898); "Der Antichrist" (1902); "Geschichte der juedischen Apologetik" (1903); "Die Religioese Bewegung innerhalb des Judenthums im Zeitalter Jesu" (1906); "Der Kreuzestod Jesu" (1906), and "Synagoge und Kirche" (1908). He also published several books on his experiences in Galicia under the name of Marek Firkowitz. Friedlander also  used the pseudonyms of: M. Freimann and Paul Frieda.

Moritz Frielander contributed to the Revue des Etudes Juives and to the Jewish Quarterly Review. He died in Vienna.

Goldstein, Josef (1837-1899), cantor, born and brought up in Neutra where his father was hazzan (cantor) and Goldstein sang in his choir from age six. His father died when Goldstein was ten and when he was 13 he took his father's place as hazzan of the community. He officiated in many Hungarian communities and studied in Prague (now in Czech Republic) before being appointed at age 18 chief cantor at Vienna's Leopoldstadt synagogue where he remained for over forty years. He introduced there the Polish style of hazzanut. 
 .

Gollancz, Victor (1893–1967), publisher, socialist, and humanitarian, born in London, England, son of a wholesale jeweller and nephew of Rabbi Professor Sir Hermann Gollancz and Professor Sir Israel Gollancz. 

Gollancz rejected his family's religious orthodoxy. After graduating from Oxford University, Gollancz was commissioned into the Northumberland Fusiliers in October 1915, although he did not see active service. In 1917 he became involved in the Reconstruction Committee, an organisation that made plans for post-World War I Britain.

He was hired to work in a publishing business. Starting with magazines, Gollancz then brought out a series of art books, after which he started recruiting novelists. Gollancz formed his own publishing company in 1927, publishing works by writers such as George Orwell. Gollancz was one of the founders of the Left Book Club whose aim was to stop Nazism and prevent the outbreak of war. When he published "The Red Army Moves" by Geoffrey Cox on the Winter War in 1941, he omitted criticisms of the USSR. 

In addition to his successful publishing business, Gollancz was a prolific writer on a variety of subjects. His 1943 pamphlet "Let My People Go", which called for the Allied powers to rescue Jews under threat of extermination in occupied Europe, reached a mass audience in 1943, following widespread coverage in the British media in December 1942 of the Nazi's extermination policy. A subsequent pamphlet on the same subject, published by Gollancz two years later, did not succeed. By then the British media had almost entirely ceased writing of the Nazi attempt to exterminate European Jewry, after it had become clear that the western powers were unwilling to rescue Jews in occupied Europe on the grounds that it would divert precious resources from the war effort. 

From 1945 he opposed Britain's pro-Arab policy in Palestine, but then proceeded to head an organization devoted to relief work for the Arabs during Israel's War of Independence. He advocated reconciliation between Jews and Germans and between Arabs and Jews. From 1952 to 1964 he was a member of the board of governors of the Hebrew University.   

In 1945 Gollancz turned his attention to crimes against the defeated Germans. He started a campaign for the humane treatment of German civilians and organised an airlift to provide Germany and other war torn European countries with  books, food and clothing from a Britain still subject to rationing. In his book, "Our Threatened Values" (London, 1946), Gollancz described the conditions Sudeten German prisoners faced in a Czech prison camp. In Britain he also worked on a campaign to abolish capital punishment in the 1950s. In February 1951 Victor Gollancz wrote a letter to "The Guardian" asking people to join an international struggle against poverty. This directly led to the founding of the international anti-poverty charity "War on Want". In 1960, he received the Peace Prize of the German Book Trade, being the first British person to receive this award. He was knighted by Queen Elizabeth II in 1965.

In 1961 he wrote a book expressing his opposition to the Trial of Adolf Eichmann.

Herman, Lipot (1881-1972), painter, born in Nagyszentmiklos, Hungary, (then part of Austria-Hungary, today in Romania). He studied in Budapest and Munich, Germany, and lived for some time in Berlin and Paris, France. While still a student, he became known as a result of  a portrait of his mother (1903), later exhibited in the Budapest Art Museum. 

Herman was one of the founders of the artists' colony of Kecskemet, Hungary, and of the Szinyei Merse Society. His exhibits in 1912, 1918 and 1922 in Budapest placed him amongst the best known Hungarian painters of his time. In addition to portraits, nudes and landscapes, he drew some battle scenes of World War I (now exhibited in the Regiments Museum, Prague, Czech Republic). Herman is known for his sensuous and colorful compositions on mythological and Biblical subjects. Some of his cartoons were published in 1921 in the form of an album. His painting "The Lovers", and his landscapes, exhibited at Brussels in 1926, were acclaimed by the Belgian press. At the exhibit of Barcelona in 1929 he was awarded the gold medal.
 
Herman became a well known art critic. His writings on contemporary Hungarian painting were published in "Magyar Muveszet", the magazine of the Szinyei Merse Society.

Born in Odessa, Russia (now Ukraine) she was the daughter of Yiddish stage actress Esther Rachel Kaminska (1870-1925) and actor, director and stage producer, Avram Izhak Kaminski (1867–1918). She was the sister of musician Josef Kaminsky (1903-1972) and cousin of actor Danny Kaye.

Ida Kaminska began a stage career at the age of five. Her first movie role was in 1912 in Mirele Efros, with her mother and her sister in other roles in the film. Her film career was brief, only appearing in four other movies in her entire career. However, in 1965, she starred in the Slovak and Czech movie The Shop on Main Street (Obchod na korze, directed by Ján Kadár and Elmar Klos), and she received a 1966 nomination for the Academy Award for Best Actress in a Leading Role.

Her last role was The Angel Levine (1970), directed by Ján Kadár.

Following her death from cardiovascular disease in 1980, she was interred in the Yiddish theater section of the Mount Hebron Cemetery in Flushing, New York.

אידה קמינסקה נולדה באודסה; הייתה בתם של השחקנית אסתר רחל קמינסקה והשחקן, במאי ומפיק אברהם יצחק קמינסקי. אחיה היה המוסיקאי יוסף קמינסקי ובן דודה היה שחקן הקולנוע דני קיי.

היא התחילה להופיע בתיאטרון בגיל חמש. תפקידה הראשון בקולנוע היה בשנת 1912 בסרט "מירלה אפרת" עם אמה ואחותה בתפקידים אחרים בסרט. הקריירה הקולנועית שלה הייתה קצרה - היא השתתפה רק בעוד ארבעה סרטים. עם זאת, בשנת 1965 היא כיכבה בסרט הצ'כוסלובקי "החנות ברחוב הראשי" וקיבלה בשנת 1966 אוסקר כשחקנית הראשית הטובה ביותר לאותה שנה. התפקיד האחרון שלה היה "המלאך לוין" בבימויו של יאן קאדאר (1970).

אידה קמינסקה נפטרה בשנת 1980 אחרי מחלת לב. היא קבורה בחלקת השחקנים היהודים בבית העלמין "הר חברון" בפלאשינג, ניו יורק.

Kardos, Laszlo (1898-1987), literary scholar and translator, born in Debrecen, Hungary (then part of Austria-Hungary). Kardos was a teacher at the Jewish high school in his native town. After World War II he worked in the Hungarian Ministry of Education until 1950, when he was appointed professor of world literature at Budapest University. 

Kardos made his name as a translator from many languages. He translated into Hungarian works from Greek, Latin, English, French, German, Czech, Polish, Romanian and Russian. His literary sensitivity enabled him to translate even from languages which he did not know fluently. With the help of expert assistants he produced an anthology of Hebrew poetry, "Heber koltok antologiaja" (1942). Kardos also edited a Hungarian periodical devoted to world literature, "Nagyvilag". His works include, "A huszonegyeves Ady Endre" (1922), "Karinthy Frigyes" (1946), "Valogatott muforditasok" (1953), and "Toth Arpad".

Lamarr, Hedy (1913-2000), actress, born as Hedwig Eva Maria Kiesler in Vienna, Austria. Her father was a Jewish banker. Cinema fascinated her and she dropped out of school as a teenager to go into acting. Her first role was in 1932 in the German Movie, "Geld Auf Der Strase".  She was discovered by the renowned stage director Max Reinhardt, and gained international notoriety by appearing naked in the Czech film ‘Ecstasy’ (1933). In the clerical-rightist regime in Vienna, the film was a sensation and caused a scandal. The film was banned in Germany because Kiesler was Jewish and in the USA because of film censorship by the Hays Office.  She made five films in Europe under the name Hedy or Hedwig Kiesler. 

Her reputation preceded her to London before she immigrated to Great Britain in 1937. A year later, she boarded the ocean liner ‘Normandie’ on her way to the USA. The renowned movie producer Louis B. Mayer saw her work and gave her a screen test. He gave her a contract for seven years and changed her name to Hedy Lamarr, in honor of the silent film star, Barbara La Marr. Soon afterwards, not yet 20 years old, she married Fritz Mandel thirty years her senior. He was a wealthy munitions manufacturer and a Nazi sympathizer. It was while married to him that Lamarr gained insight into munitions that was to be so important for her work during World War II. 

Lamarr's first Hollywood film was "'Algiers" (1938), in which she played with Charles Boyer. It brought her immediate stardom. Following this success she was cast with top leading actors like: Robert Taylor in "Lady Of The Tropics" (1938), Spencer Tracy in "I Take This Woman" (!940), Clark Gable in "Boom Town" (1940), and  "Comrade X" (1940). In the 1940s she was among the stars of MGM and was thought the most beautiful and glamorous woman in Hollywood. Her performance opposite Robert Young in "H. M. Pulman Esq." (1941) was probably her best. During her Hollywood film career, Lamarr played in over 25 movies. Among the most notable were "Tortilla Flat" (1942) and "White Cargo" (1942). Her contract with MGM terminated with the comedy "Her Highness and the Bellboy" (1945). Lamarr then formed her own production company to play a femme fatale in "The Strange Woman" (1946) and in "Dishonored Lady" (1947). Her popularity began to decline even after De Mille chose her as Victor Mature’s devious mate in "Samson and Delila" (1949). She played in "Lady Without Passport" (1950) and in Bob Hope’s "My Favorite Spy" (1951).

About the beginning of World War II Lamarr became acquainted with a musician, George Anthiel. They discussed what they could do to aid the USA war effort and Lamarr, based on the knowledge she gained during her marriage to Mandel, knew that a torpedo that could be guided was more effective than the radio-controlled used by the USA. Between them, they came up with the idea of how to change frequencies using a player-piano roll developed by Anthiel.  They offered their invention to the USA, but it was never taken seriously. Lamarr, however, continued working for the war effort and raised money for bonds by selling kisses for $50,000.

Following her successes through the 1950s her movie career continued to suffer. Lamarr’s somewhat stiff and unyielding personality did not match her beauty. She was temperamental and choosy about her roles. She turned down acting in "Casablanca", "Gaslight" and "Saratoga Trunk". Her part as Joan of Arc in "The Story of Mankind" (1957) was badly miscast. In "The Female Animal" (1957), she virtually played herself as an aging movie star.

In the 1950's the Sylvania Company came across Lamarr's and Anthiel's invention and used it during the Cuban Missile crisis. In 2000 Lamarr was given the Electronic Frontier Foundation award for their invention. Anthiel however, also honored, had died much earlier. One of Lamarr's sons accepted the award for her. Lamarr had been married and divorced six times and had three children with her third husband, John Loder. She died, in retirement, in Florida on January 19, 2000

Neumann, Moses Samuel (1769-1831), Hebrew author and educator, born in Ban, Hungary (then part of the Austrain Empire). He started to study at the yeshivah of Boskovitz at the age of 12 and, subsequently became a pupil of the orientalist Baruch Jeitteles at Prague (now in the Czech Republic). From 1799 he tutored at Pozsony, Hungary (now Bratislava, Slovakia) and Vienna. From 1822 until his death he lived at Pest (now Budapest). 

Neumann published "Biur Milloth Lerambam" (with the Hebrew commentary of Moses Mendelssohn; 1822). His Hebrew poems "Shire Musar" (1814) and his drama "Bath Yiftah" (1815) revealed him as a classic scholar of the Hebrew tongue. Neumann was author also of a number of pedagogical works in Hebrew, including: "Maagal Yosher" (3rd ed., 1831), and a Hebrew grammar; "Hinnuch Leshon Ibrith" (1815), a theoretical and practical grammar; "Rosh Emunah" (1820), a book of religious instruction; "Hakaddur", a mathematical geography. He also compiled biblical stories and an elementary arithmetic primer "His Michtebe Ibrith" (4th ed., 1834) was the first Hebrew-German letter writer. His pedagogical ideas were subsequently employed in religious instruction in many yeshivot.

Pollak, Hayim (1834-1905), author and educator, born in Liptoszentmiklos, Hungary (then part of the Austrian Empire, now Liptovski Svaty Mikulas, Slovakia).  After receiving a Talmudic education in his native town, Pollack studied at the Yeshivot of Pozsony, (Pressburg, now Bratislava, Slovakia), Sateraljaujhely, Hungary, and also at Prague (now in Czech Republic). He taught at various Jewish public schools in Hungary, including that of Obuda (Altofen), where he was retained on the staff after the city of Budapest took over the school.

Pollak was the author of a Hebrew-Hungarian dictionary (1880), the first of its kind. In addition he published "Valogatott Gyongyok" ("Choice of Pearls"),a translation of Solomon ibn Gabirol's "Mivhar Hapeninim"; "Megillath Antiochus" (1886), with Hebrew notes; "Tikkun Middot ha-Nefesh" (1895); "Izrael nepenek multjabol" (1898; German translation, "Die Erinnerung an die Vorfahren", 1902), a history of mourning customs; "Josefinische Aktenstuecke ueber Alt-Ofen" (1902). From 1882 to 1883, he edited the journal "Jesurun", founded to combat anti-Semitism.

פולק, חיים (1834-1905), סופר ומחנך, נולד בליפטוסנמיקלוש, הונגריה (אז חלק מהאימפריה האוסטרית, (עכשיו ליפטובסקי סוויאטי מיקולס, סלובקיה). לאחר שקיבל חינוך תלמודי בעיר מולדתו, פולק למד בישיבות של פוז'וני, (פרשבורג, כיום ברטיסלבה, סלובקיה), שאטוראליה, הונגריה, וגם בפראג (כיום בצ'כיה). הוא לימד במגוון בבתי ספר ציבוריים יהודים בהונגריה, כולל זה של אובודה (Altofen), שבו הוא נשאר בסגל גם אחרי שבית הספר עבר לריבונותה של העיר בודפשט. 

פולק היה מחברו של המילון ההונגרי-עברי הראשון (1880). בנוסף הוא פרסם תרגום להונגרית של "מבחר פנינים" של שלמה אבן-גבירול, "מגילת אנטיוכוס" (1886), "תיקון מידות הנפש" (1895), וספר בהונגרית על מנהגי האבלות בעם היהודי (1898). ספר זה תורגם לגרמנית בשנת 1902.

text_en:
Rosenthal, Salomon (1745-1845), scholar, born in Mor, Hungary (then part of the Austrian Empire), where his father, Naphtali Rosenthal, a renowned Talmudist, founded the local Jewish community. Salomon studied under Mordecai Benet of Nikolsburg (now Mikulov, Czech Republic) at one time a pupil of his father, and under Meir Barbi of Pressburg (Pozsony, now Bratislava, Slovakia). He engaged in business at Mor and pursued Jewish studies in his leisure time. 

In 1819 he moved to Pest, where he published "Beth Aven" (1839), assailing Creizenach, Luzzatto and Reggio. In addition to scholarly contributions to "Ha'Meassef", "Orient" and "Zion", Rosenthal published Leon da Modena's Cabalistic work "Ari Nohem", with a preface and notes of his own. He corresponded with Wolfgang Wessely of Prague and Issac Euchel, and left behind the manuscript of his complete Hebrew translation of Moses Mendelssohn's "Phaedon".

Rosenzweig, Adolf (1850-1918), rabbi and author, born in Turdossin, Hungary (then part of the Austrian Empire, now Tvrdošín, Slovakia). He studied at the Gymnasium of Pest, at the Yeshivah of Pressburg, Hungary (now Bratislava, Slovakia), and at the university and rabbinical seminary of Berlin, Germnay. He received his Ph.D. degree from the University of Leipzig. After serving as rabbi in Pasewalk, Birnbaum, Posen (now Poznan, Poland) and Teplitz (now Teplice, Czech Republic), he served in Berlin from 1887 until his death. 

His works deal mostly with historical and archeological subjects. Rosenzweig wrote: "Das Jahrhundert nach dem babylonischen Exile mit besonderer Rueksicht auf die religioese Entwicklung des Judentums" (1885); "Der politische und religioese Charakter des Flavius Josephus" (1889); "Geselligkeit und Geselligkeitsfreunde in Bibel und Talmud" (1895); "Kleidung und Schmuk im biblischen und talmudischen Schrifttum" (1905), and "Die Al-Tikri Deutungen" (1911). Rosenzweig died at Kolberg, Germany (now Kołobrzeg, in Poland).

Roth, Pedro (1938- ), art photographer, painter and cartoonist born in Budapest, Hungary, and who emigrated to Argentina in 1954. He graduated in filmmaking  from the National University of La Plata and then studied art photography at the Metropolitan Museum in New York, USA. For over forty years Roth is an important player in many aspects of the culture of the City of Buenos Aires. He was the preferred photographer of the works of all major Argentinian artists, while at the same time he developed his own creative work through both painting and photography. He became known too as a cartoonist with a very distinctive style. Exhibitions of his work have been held throughout the Americas and Europe.

A creator and promoter of cultural ideas, Roth participated in a major Czech-Argentine cultural project which paid tribute to the pioneer of artificial intelligence, the Golem.

Schreter (Szreter), Zygmunt (1886-1977), painter born in Lodz, Poland (then part of the Russian Empire), the son of Max Schretera, manufacturer of textiles, and his wife Rose. Schreter studied in Berlin, Germany, at the workshop of Louis Corinth at the frre academy of Levine Funke. 

The first contact  Zygmunt Schreter had with the graphics was at his father's factory, where he drew textile patterns. In addition, he was musically gifted and was trained by his mother to play the violin. At the the outbreak of World War I in 1914, he stayed with his father who had been interned in Karlsbad (now Karlovy Vary, Czech Republic). In Berlin Schreter was a violinist with the Berlin Philarmonic Orchestra and with the orchestra of Max-Reinhart's theater.  

After WW1 he remained in Berlin, where he was associated with the environment of the Russian and Jewish emigration. In 1927 he first exhibited his works in Lodz, another exhibition took place in 1932 and 1933. In 1932 where his work was exhibited for the first time in Paris at the Salon des Tuileries. In 1934 he moved to Paris permanently, quickly became involved in the artistic life of the French capital. He painted portraits of people with their environment, and views of the French countryside, into which he traveled frequently. He participated in many exhibitions, including Autumn salons. 

His work was heavily influenced by Cézanne. Schreter visited Poland for last time in 1937 when he attended the opening of an exhibition of his work. He survived World War II by hiding in Paris. Although already in the mid 1930s he was introduced to the public as a French artist, he was awarded French citizenship only in 1960. In many publications Zygmunt Schreter is considered to be a French painter.

Seligsohn, Ernst (?1890-?1970), jurist, born in Berlin, Germany. His father Dr. Martin Seligsohn had been a lawyer in Berlin and was in partnership in Berlin with his brother Dr. Arnold Seligsohn. Their firm specialized in intellectual property law such as patents, copyright, trademarks etc.   Arnold wrote a textbook on German patent law and was a lecturer on this at the Berlin University. Their respective sons also studied law, the both specialized in the same field as their respective fathers whose practice they ultimately joined.   

When the Nazis prevented Jews from practicing law in April 1933 Ernst, who had married Lily Katz from Kassel, Germany, and now had two small children, at first sought to move their firm from Berlin to Prague, Czech Republic (then in Czechoslovakia). When this was not practicable, the family decided to move to Palestine. In January 1934 Ernst and his family together with his father Martin and his family arrived in Tel Aviv. In order to practice law in Mandatory Palestine Seligsohn had to teach himself a new legal system, a new language and environment. He opened his practice in 1940 and wished to specialize in intellectual property law as he had done in Germany. This was financially viable only in the late 1960s.   

His was one of the first Palestine lawyers who had expertise in this field and was involved in almost all important cases in Israel during the first decades of the new state. He lectured on the field at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem. He was a member of the ministerial committees which prepared the Israel Patent Law and the Copyright Law. He also wrote Israel’s first textbook on trademark law (1972). A product of Germany’s prewar intellectual and cultural society, Seligsohn was very well versed in literature, music and the arts.

Spitzer, Samuel (1839-1896), rabbi and scholar born in Keszthely, Hungary (then part of the Austrian Empire). He studied with Rabbi Salomon Judah Rapaport in Prague (now in the Czech Republic). And in 1856 he became rabbi of Eszek, Hungary (now Osijek, Croatia), where he engaged in the study of the history of Jewish and general culture.

His published works include: "Das Heer und Wehrgesetz der alten Israeliten, Griechen und Roemer" (1869); "Die juedische Ehe" (1869); "Die Juedische Gemeindeordnung" (1873); "Das Mahl bei den alten Voelkern" (1878); "Urheimisch in slavischen Laendern" (1880); "Das Jubileaum in woertlicher und historischer Beleuchtung" (1882); "Das Blut-gespenst auf seine wahre Quelle zurueckgefuert" (1883); "Das religioese Bedenken o. Kann man d. Eid vor einem Andersglaubugen ablegen?" (1883); "Ueber Baden und Baader bei den Alten" (1883); "Die Uhr bei der Alten" (1885); "Ueber Sitte und Sitten der alten Voelker" (1886), and "Der Brief bei den alten Voelkern" (1893).

Szanto, Simon (1819-1882), educator and writer, born in Nagykanizsa, Hungary (then part of the Austrian Empire). Son of a rabbi, he received a strict religious upbringing in the Talmudic schools of Kackenbach and Golcuv-Jenikov, Bohemia (now in the Czech Republic), and managed under great difficulties to obtain a secular education in Bratislava (now in Slovakia) and at Prague University, where he studied German literature. He also studied Jewish theology under S. J. Rapoport, and was ordained a rabbi in 1844. 

In 1845 he moved to Vienna, where he founded an elementary and secondary school for boys in 1849, which combined Jewishness with modern secular learning. It became the first Jewish school in Austria entitled to issue officially valid diplomas. Szanto taught Bible and Hebrew literature at the Vienna Beit ha-Midrash; he was also appointed inspector for Jewish religious instruction at public schools and official interpreter of the Hebrew language, and became a lecturer at the Theologische Lehrantstalt. 

In 1861 he founded, with Leopold Kompert, a weekly journal, "Die Neuzeit", which he edited until his death. He contributed to the "Jahrbuch fuer Israeliten" and was its editor from 1865 to 1868.

Szanto was a prolific writer with a precise and lively style, writing a large portion of "Die Neuzeit" himself as well as many articles in the Jewish and Vienna daily press, chiefly on education. He wrote: "Bocer Olelosz" (a Bible commentary, 1845), two historic novels: "Bilder aus Alexandrias Vorzeit" and "Judentum und Romantik"; "Schullerers Paradaxa"; "Fahrende Juden"; "Sturmpetition eines Paedagogen"; "Musterung zur Charakteristik der Erzieherwelt" (1857-1858); "Schematismus der israelit. Cultusgemeinden in der Oesterr. Monarchie" (1869), and "Ibn Karmi" (pseudonim, 1871).  

Szanto also wrote  many essays on Jewish history, some in Hebrew. He was a devoted follower of Adolf Jellinek and a forceful fighter for his ideas of Jewish reform, and he participated in the Reform synods of Leipzig and Augsburg.

Luka

German: Luck

A village and municipality, Liberec Region, Czech Republic

According to tradition, Jews from Bavaria founded the town in the 11th century; there are local records of Jews living in the town in 1198. 

Records from 1432 mention a Jewish "place of worship." Later, in 1842, the synagogue and community records were damaged in a fire. 

During the Thirty Years' War (1618-1648) the community was nearly decimated by the plague.
 
The Jews from Luka, like those from Hroznetin (German: Lichtenstadt), did business in nearby Carlsbad. 

During the 19th century Feibel (Phillip) Kohn served as the mayor for 28 years. A Reform and an Orthodox rabbi served the community.
   
In 1848, Jews throughout the Austrian Empire, including Luka, were emancipated and residence and economic restrictions were subsequently lifted. As a result, many Jews throughout the region began moving to larger towns and cities, seeking greater economic and educational opportunities. In Luka, Jews had begun moving elsewhere even before 1848 and the emancipation served only to accelerate the community's decline. In 1850 there were 1,150 Jews lived in Luka (80% of the total population). By 1869 the population had dropped to 446. By 1930 there were not enough Jews living in Luka for a minyan.
 
THE HOLOCAUST

By the time the Nazis invaded, few to no Jews were living in Luka. On November 10, 1938,the Nazis burned down the synagogue. They also sold tombstones from the Jewish cemetery to a stonemason.
text_he:
לוקה LUKA

(בגרמנית: LUCK)

עיירה במערב בוהמיה, חבל הסודטים, צ'כיה.


לוקה שוכנת כ-80 ק"מ ממערב לפראג. עד 1918 היה האזור בקיסרות אוסטריה-הונגריה ומאז עד 1993 ברפובליקה הצ'כוסלובקית.

על-פי המסורת נוסדה לוקה בידי חוטבי-עצים יהודים שבאו למקום מבאוואריה במאה ה-11. יהודים תועדו שם לראשונה ברשימות הכמורה המקומית מ-1198. ואמנם אין לנו מידע על חיי היהודים באותם ימים, אבל הם מתועדים בהקשר לגביע שהכינו אומנים יהודים בני המקום למלך אוטוקאר פשמיסל השני (1278-1253), שיצא לביקור אצל האפיפיור.

ב-1439 נזכר בלוקה בעל אחוזה יהודי, שהקים שם בית תפילה.

יהודי לוקה, שחיו במאה ה-17 בחסות האצילים, היו בעלי זכויות יותר מיהודי ישובים אחרים בסביבה. במהלך מלחמת שלושים השנה (1648-1618) ניספו יהודים רבים במגיפת דבר.

מראשית המאה ה-18 היו בלוקה בית ספר עברי, "חדר" שבו לימדו בשפה הגרמנית וארבע כיתות ראשונות של בית ספר ריאלי יהודי. ב-1840 העסיקה הקהילה שלושה מורים בשכר.

בין מוסדות הקהילה היו גם מקוה, בית מטבחיים ומאפיית מצות.

בדליקה שפרצה בלוקה ב-1842 נשרפו בית הכנסת ורוב מסמכי הקהילה. ב-1850 ישבו בלוקה 1,150 יהודים והיו %80 באוכלוסיית העיירה. היו שם רב אורתודוקסי, חזן, שמש ודרשן רפורמי. בין רבני הקהילה היה הרב ליאופולד פרידלאנדר (FRIEDLANDER).

בין השנים 1905-1882 כיהנו לסרוגין כראשי הקהילה וכראשי העיירה: עמנואל קלאובר (KLAUBER), פיליפ (פייבל) כהן והרמאן אולמאן (ULLMANN). בימי כהונת פייבל כהן תוקנו תקנות "חברה קדישא" מחדש, הוקם בית כנסת חדש, שופצו המקוה ובית המטבחיים, וב-1864 הוקם בית קהילה בן שתי קומות. לנשפי פורים שארגנה הקהילה ולארועים שנערכו בחג הסוכות ובחג החנוכה באו גם יהודים מיישובי הסביבה. ב-1905 נבחר אלברט הירש (HIRSCH) לראש הקהילה. בין השנים 1919-1905 שימשה טירה קטנה מתקופת הרנסאנס כבית יתומים לילדים יהודים מפראג.

בין היהודים הראשונים שישבו בלוקה עסקו רבים במסחר בעיר הסמוכה קארלובי-וארי (KARLOVY VARY). מהמחצית השנייה של המאה ה-19 היו בין יהודי לוקה תעשיינים ובעלי מקצועות חופשיים רבים.

בעקבות האמנציפציה של יהודי קיסרות אוסטריה (1848) השתלבו היהודים בחיי הציבור ובפוליטיקה. ראש הקהילה פייבל כהן היה חבר בנציגות יהודי בוהמיה. במשך 28 שנות כהונתו כראש העיירה פותחה לוקה, נבנו גשרים, רוצפה הככר, הונהגו סדרי תנועה חדשים ונפתח סניף דאר שנוהל בידי יהודים.

ברפובליקה הצ'כוסלובקית שבין שתי מלחמות העולם (1938-1918) הוכרו היהודים כמיעוט לאומי. ראש הקהילה, אלברט הירש, שהיה יושב ראש אזורי של "המפלגה היהודית", נבחר ברוב גדול לראשות העיירה גם על-ידי תושבים לא-יהודים.

עוד לפני 1848, השנה שבה בוטלו הגבלות ההתיישבות של יהודי הקיסרות, החלו יהודי לוקה לעבור ליישובים הגדולים, אבל משנות השמונים למאה ה-19 גברה העקירה לערים פראג, וינה וקארלובי- וארי, וגם הגירה לארצות שמעבר לים. ב-1869 נותרו בעיירה 446 יהודים.

ב-1930 ישבו בלוקה רק יהודים אחדים.


תקופת השואה

חיי שיתוף-פעולה של מאות שנים בין היהודים לנוצרים בלוקה באו לקיצם בעקבות תעמולה נאצית של מפלגת הנליין (HENLEIN), שרוב מתושבי העיירה נהיו חברים בה. המפלגה פעלה למען סיפוח חבל הסודטים לגרמניה ונגד היהודים. החבל סופח בסופו של דבר לרייך השלישי בעקבות הסכם מינכן מ-30 בספטמבר 1938; רוב היהודים נמלטו. ב-10 בנובמבר 1938, ב"ליל הבדולח" עלה בניין בית הכנסת באש, וכל ציודו ותשמישי הקדושה נשרפו. באותו לילה נרצחו כמה יהודים. שתי אחיות קשישות נמלטו מפני הפורעים אל תוך הנהר אנאטייך (ANNATEICH) ושם טבעו. הן היו האחרונות שנקברו בבית העלמין היהודי.

אחרי פרוץ מלחמת העולם השנייה (ספטמבר 1939), הרסו הגרמנים את רוב המצבות העתיקות בבית העלמין ואת המצבות החדשות מכרו לחוצב אבנים בקארלובי-וארי.

יהודים יוצאי לוקה, שנמלטו לפנים צ'כיה (בוהמיה ומוראוויה), נלקחו ב-1942 לגיטו טרזין (THERESIENSTADT). משם שולחו למחנות ריכוז והשמדה.

מקהילת לוקה נותרו רק שרידי בית העלמין הנטוש.

text_en:
Miroslav

German: Misslitz

A town in the Znojmo District, Czech Republic

The Jewish cemetery contains tombstones that date from the late 17th century through the 20th century, as well as a pre-burial house and monuments to Jewish soldiers. The cemetery is owned by the Jewish community of Brno, and can be accessed freely. 

HISTORY

It is believed that the first Jews settled in Miroslav after they were expelled from the Moravian royal cities in 1454. Records from the Ottoman-Hapsburg wars (16th-18th centuries) mention a Jewish community in the town. That community subsequently dwindled to only three families, but the population began to recover when it began absorbing refugees from the Chmielnicki Massacres (1648-1649). In 1666 there were 20 Jews who were expelled from the town. Jews from Vienna later settled in the town, bringing the town's total Jewish population to 18 families. Legally 119 Jewish families were permitted to live in Miroslav. 

In 1753 there were 64 families living in 18 houses. By 1801 there were 448 Jews (18% of the total population) living in the town, a number that did not change by 1820. 

In 1831 local Jewish resident Rafael Koenig (b. 1808) became the first Jewish locksmith in the Hapsburg Empire. 

A Reform-style synagogue was built in 1845. An independent Jewish political community was established in 1867; it was later incorporated into the municipality in 1924. 

The Jewish population reached its peak in 1857, when it numbered 1,032 people. With the removal of residence restrictions after the 1848 emancipation of Jews throughout the Austrian Empire, many Jews began moving to larger towns and cities, seeking greater economic and educational opportunities and greatly reducing the populations of smaller towns and villages. The Jewish population of Miroslav subsequently declined to 424 in 1869, though it rose slightly, to 528 people, in 1900. During World War I approximately 350 refugees fled to Miroslav, but few settled there permanently. In 1930 the community numbered 291 people (6.6% of the total). 

THE HOLOCAUST

In March, 1939 the region of Bohemia and Moravia became a protectorate of Nazi Germany, ushering in a period of discrimination and violence against the Jews living there. The Jewish community of Miroslav was sent to the Terezin (Theresienstadt) Ghetto in 1942. From there they were deported to concentration and death camps, where most perished. Before the community was sent to Terezin, ritual objects and synagogue equipment from Miroslav was sent to the Central Jewish Museum in Prague.

POSTWAR

Many of the buildings that stood in the Jewish Quarter were preserved. In 1999 students from the Czech Republic, Germany, Poland, the Netherlands, and Slovakia worked to restore the Jewish cemetery in Miroslav.
text_he:
מירוסלאב Miroslav

(בגרמנית MISSLITZ)

עיר בדרום מוראוויה, חבל הסודטים, צ'כיה.


מירוסלאב שוכנת 15 ק"מ מדרום לעיר פוהוז'ליצה (POHORELICE). עד 1918 השתייכה לקיסרות אוסטריה ומאז ועד 1993 לרפובליקה הצ'כוסלובקית.

היהודים הראשונים במירוסלאב היו כנראה אלה שגורשו ב-1454 מהערים המלכותיות ברנו (BRNO) וזנוימו (ZNOJMO) ומצאו מקלט באחוזות האצולה שבאזור. בימי מלחמת אוסטריה בטורקים הייתה קהילה יהודית משגשגת בעיר, אך במהלך מלחמת שלושים השנה (1648-1618) הצטמצמה לשלוש משפחות. מספר היהודים בעיר עלה שוב כאשר פליטי פרעות ת"ח ות"ט (חמלניצקי, 1648) מפולין הגיעו למוראוויה.

ב-1666 גירש השליט המקומי, הגראף מנאכוד, 20 יהודים מהעיר. ב-1670 באו למירוסלאב פליטים יהודים שגורשו מווינה וב-1672 ישבו בעיר 18 משפחות יהודיות ב-18 בתים. ב-1727 הופרד "הרחוב היהודי" משאר חלקי העיר. "חוק הכרזת המשפחות" (1726) של הקיסר קארל ה-VI אמנם התיר ל-119 משפחות יהודיות לשבת במירוסלאב, אבל ב-1753 עדיין היו ליהודים רק 18 בתים ובהם ישבו 64 משפחות.

בשריפות בשנים 1794 ו-1798 נפגעו שני שליש מבתי היהודים. אחרי השריפה של 1789 הוקצו לתושבים מגרשים לבנייה, ובראשית המאה ה-19, אחרי שהקיסר קבע שהבתים ב"רחוב היהודי" במירוסלאב רעועים ודלים, הורחב גם הרובע היהודי.

רק ב-1801 הגיע מספר המשפחות ל-119 (448 נפשות) והיהודים היו 18 אחוזים מכלל התושבים. ב-1820 גרו 119 המשפחות היהודיות ב-94 בתים, רובן בדירות בנות חדר אחד.

לשיא גודלה הגיעה הקהילה ב-1857 ומנתה 1,032 יהודים. אחר כך החלה ירידה הדרגתית במספרם וב-1900 חיו במירוסלאב 528 יהודים.

המצבות העתיקות ביותר שזוהו בבית העלמין היהודי היו מהשנים 1691 ו-1693. בית העלמין הורחב במשך השנים, וכשהתמלא פתחו שכבה נוספת בקברים הישנים. בית לוויות הוקם ב- 1902. ב-1921 נקבע בבית העלמין לוח לזכר 13 בני הקהילה שנפלו במלחמת העולם הראשונה. במקום קבורים גם פליטים יהודים ממזרח אירופה, שמתו שם במהלך המלחמה. תקנות "חברה קדישא" תוקנו לראשונה ב-1863 ובפעם השלישית ב-1927.

בית כנסת נחנך ב-1845, והונהג בו נוסח תפילה וינאי למרות התנגדות השמרנים. ב-1897 נוסף לבית הכנסת אגף למקהלה וב-1926 שופץ הבניין והותקנה בו תאורה חשמלית.

במרכז "העיר היהודית" שכנו גם בית חולים יהודי ודירת הרב. ב-1896 הוקם מתרומות בית לעניים וב-1827 הוקם בית קהילה חדש שבו שכנו בית הספר, משרדי הקהילה, ספרייה, המקוה, ודירות עובדי בית הכנסת. גם בית התפילה עבר לשם.

מראשית ימי הקהילה למדו ילדי הקהילה לימודי עברית ותנ"ך, ולימודי המשך של תלמוד ומשנה. מלמדים מתועדים במקום משנת 1753.

בעקבות "צו הסובלנות" (1782) של הקיסר יוזף השני חוייבה הקהילה לפתוח בית ספר יהודי בשפה הגרמנית ולהעסיק מורה מוסמך. בקרב יהודי העיר לא היה מורה כזה ותחילה לימד בבית הספר מורה מטעם הכנסייה. המורה היהודי הראשון, פיליפ ופנשטיין (WAPPENSTEIN), נתמנה ב-1790. באמצע המאה ה-19 התנהלו הלימודים בשלוש כיתות, בגרמנית ובעברית. ב- 1870 היו בבית הספר שתי כיתות, בית הספר הוכר כמוסד חינוכי פתוח וב-1873 נרשם בו מספר שיא של תלמידים - 138. בשנות השמונים נוספו שיעורי מלאכה. בין השנים 1914-1890 למדו שם גם ילדים מקהילות יהודיות סמוכות. ב-1920, בתקופת הרפובליקה הצ'כוסלובקית, חייבו ללמד את השפה הצ'כית בבתי הספר. מספר התלמידים ירד ל-16 וב-1923 נאלצה הקהילה לסגור את בית הספר היהודי. בעיר פעלו גם בתי ספר פרטיים.

עד שנת 1848 כונו ראשי הקהל "שופטי-היהודים" (JUDENRICHTER). מ-1753, עד שנות השלושים של המאה ה-20, מתועדים למעלה משלושים ראשי קהל, ביניהם סלומון בן אברהם, שנפטר בשנת 1755, תמך בעניים ותרם ספר תורה לקהילה, ומאיר בן סלומון שנפטר ב- 1833, ותרם גם הוא ספר תורה וכלי כסף לבית הכנסת.

רבנים כיהנו בעיר כנראה מראשית המאה ה-18. הראשון היה הרב מנחם ברונשוויק (BRUNSCHWIK), הוא נפטר ב-1720. במאה ה-20 כיהנו הרבנים ד"ר מוריץ באואר (BAUER) (1898 - 1902), הרב ד"ר נחום שורשטיין (SCHORSTEIN 1912-1903), הרב פרופסור בלה דיאמנט (DIAMANT 1920-1912) וד"ר ארנסט רייך (REICH) שנבחר ב-1922.

אגודת נשים לפעולות צדקה וסעד נוסדה ב-1886, ופעלו בקהילה אגודת צדקה, ו"תלמוד תורה". ב-1867 נעשתה הקהילה "קהילה פוליטית" (POLITISCHE GEMEINDE) בעלת עצמאות מוניציפאלית, ולעיר היהודית מונה ראש עירייה יהודי. ב-1924 אוחדה העיר היהודית עם העיר הנוצרית והיהודים היו מיוצגים במועצת העיר. באותה העת נבחר איזידור דויטש (DEUTSCH) לכהונת ראש הקהילה.

במלחמת העולם הראשונה (1918-1914) באו לעיר כ-350 פליטים יהודים מהמזרח, והקהילה סייעה להם. לילדים היהודים מגליציה נפתח בית ספר בפולנית וילדים מבוקובינה למדו בבית הספר הגרמני. אחרי המלחמה חזרו רוב הפליטים למולדתם.

ב-1927 עדיין כיהן איזידור דויטש כראש הקהילה, ושני חזנים פעלו שם. בקהילה היו אז 450 נפשות, מהם 145 משלמי מסים.

רוב הזמן הייתה פרנסת יהודי מירוסלאב בעיקר על המסחר ועל המלאכה. באמצע המאה ה-18 נרשמו במירוסלאב 13 סוחרים יהודים שסחרו בכותנה, עורות, פרוות, קמח ודגים. הם סחרו גם בשוקי הערים הסמוכות. בין המפרנסים היהודים היו גם 11 חייטים, חמישה מבשלי יין-שרף, שלושה קצבים, שני מתקני בגדים, ספר אחד ו-12 רוכלים. 13 עניים נזקקי סעד היו אז בקהילה. היהודי רפאל קוניג (KOENIG) ממירוסלאב היה ב-1831 המסגר היהודי הראשון בקיסרות.

עד לאמנציפציה של יהודי הקיסרות (1848) חיו יהודי מירוסלאב בצפיפות ורובם התפרנסו בקושי, אחר-כך שופר מצבם. במחצית השנייה של המאה ה-19 נוספו לסוחרים ולבעלי המלאכה היהודים גם בעלי מקצועות חופשיים ואקדמאים.

בין היהודים ילידי מירוסלאב היו המחזאי והעתונאי בגרמנית יעקב הרצוג (HERZOG), המשורר ארמין ברונר (BRUNNER 1929-1864) והסופר ארנסט מילר (MUELLER).

פעילות ציונית התחילה במירוסלאב עוד לפני מלחמת העולם הראשונה; ב-1913 נפתח במקום מועדון ספורט "הכח". בימי הרפובליקה הצ'כוסלובקית שבין שתי מלחמות העולם הייתה ביעיר פעילות פוליטית ופעילות ציונית ערה. נפתחו סניפים של "האגודה הציונית" ושל תנועות הנוער "תכלת לבן" ו"מכבי הצעיר". לקראת הקונגרס הציוני ה-ט"ו (1927) נמכרו במירוסלאב 92 שקלים, וב-1937 השתתפו 51 מבני הקהילה בבחירות לקונגרס הציוני ה-כ', 42 מהם הצביעו בעד "הציונים הכלליים".

ב-1930 חיו במירוסלאב 291 יהודים, %6.6 באוכלוסייה.


תקופת השואה

בעקבות הסכם מינכן מספטמבר 1938, כשנה לפני פרוץ מלחמת העולם השנייה, סופח חבל הסודטים לגרמניה והרפובליקה הצ'כוסלובקית התפרקה. רוב יהודי חבל הסודטים עקרו לפנים צ'כיה (בוהמיה ומורוויה). באמצע מארס 1939 נכנס הצבא הגרמני לצ'כיה והמדינה נעשתה פרוטקטוראט של גרמניה הנאצית. חוקי נירנברג הגזעניים הוחלו גם על יהודי צ'כיה והם הורחקו בהדרגה מחיי הציבור ומחיי הכלכלה. ב-1939, לפני פרוץ המלחמה, הצליחו יהודים מעטים ממירוסלאב להמלט לארץ ישראל, לארצות הברית ולאנגליה.

בסוף שנת 1941 החלו הגרמנים לרכז את יהודי הפרוטקטוראט בגיטו טרזין (THERESIENSTADT) ומשם גירשו אותם למחנות ריכוז ולמחנות השמדה.

לפני הגירוש הועברו 63 תשמישי קדושה של הקהילה למוזיאון היהודי המרכזי בפראג.

שרידי הרובע היהודי נפגעו בהפצצה מהאוויר בשנת 1945.


בתום המלחמה, ב-1945, חזרו למירוסלאב שבע משפחות יהודיות ששרדו, סך הכל 17 נפשות. הם ניצלו בגלל היותם בעלי מלאכה.

בראשית שנות התשעים למאה ה-20 עדיין חיו במירוסלאב שני יהודים כבני 85. ב-1993 שופץ ונוקה בית העלמין היהודי העתיק. בניין בית הכנסת הוסב עוד קודם לכן לבית תרבות.

text_en:
Boskovice

German: Boskowitz

A town in south Moravia, Czech Republic

The town of Boskovice was founded during the 15th century and is located about 20 miles (32km) northeast of Brno, the capital of Moravia. Until 1918 the area was part of the Austro-Hungarian Empire. After the collapse of the empire following World War I, and until 1993, it was part of the Republic of Czechoslovakia. Since 1993 it has been part of the Czech Republic. 

Of Boskovice's three synagogues, only the Great Synagogue survived World War II. Conservation and restoration work was carried out during the late 1980s, and by 1994 most of the structural issues and exterior conservation work had been done. Between 2000 and 2002 the remaining preservation work was carried out, thanks to grants from a number of organizations, including the World Monument Fund's Jewish Heritage Program. The fully restored building remains standing in its original location. 

The location of Boskovice's first cemetery is unknown. However, a second cemetery, which was most likely established during the 17th century, still exists. The tomb of Rabbi Samuel ben Nathan HaLevi Kolin, the author of Makhatsit HaShekel and the director of the town's yeshiva for more than 60 years, can be found there. 

Since 1993 the town has hosted an annual summer cultural festival dedicated to preserving and restoring the town's Jewish quarter. 

HISTORY

The Jewish community of Boskovice was among the oldest in Moravia; during the reign of Karl IV in the 14th century it was also one of the largest. A tombstone from the year 1069 is the earliest evidence of a Jewish presence in Boskovice; later, a court document from 1243 also evidences a Jewish presence there. In 1454 the Jews were expelled from the royal towns of Moravia (free towns not under regional jurisdiction) and some, particularly from Brno, came to Boskovice. Jewish residence was limited to a Jewish street, and on Sundays and Christian holidays Jews were forbidden from entering other parts of the town. 

The overcrowding in the Jewish Quarter could be dangerous; in 1715 an epidemic broke out within the Jewish Quarter, leaving 892 dead and the Jewish Quarter quarantined for a year. A fire that broke out on May 1, 1823 destroyed the entire Jewish Quarter, along with 20 houses from the Christian part of the town.
